summary.seg: This manuscript, probably copied in the late 12th or 13th century, is a Menaion, the liturgical book containing elements of the office peculiar to each day of the fixed calendar. These include hymns and lives of the saints whose feast is celebrated on that day, to be read during the service. The level of detail provided in Menaia varies. This example is a short version, in which hymns are merely identified by their opening line and saints' lives are in an abridged form. While in the fuller version of the text the feasts of each month might fill a manuscript, in this case this single volume covers six months, from March to August, the second half of the year in the Byzantine calendar.

The standard of the manuscript is relatively modest. It is ornamented, but in a simple and often rather crude style, while the hand of the scribe who copied the bulk of the text is not especially elegant. In the last few folios another scribe with a more assured hand took over, the change made conspicuous by the bolder colours of ink used. This was evidently still part of the original process of production, rather than a replacement of lost leaves, as the transition occurs between recto and verso of one folio.

The manuscript retains an early endleaf, reused from a somewhat older manuscript, probably of the later 11th or earlier 12th century. It contains the end of the Life of St Anthony by Athanasios of Alexandria, and is bound in back-to-front and upside-down at the front of the manuscript.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a] + i | 1-183 + [b], in pencil, in Arabic and Roman numerals, recto, upper right.

binding.p: 18th-century full leather binding over millboards, with plain pastedowns. There is decorative blind tooling on the edges of the boards, gold tooling on the spine and the title Kalendar. Grecum M.S. tooled in gold on a red label.

history.acquisition:
Bequeathed to the college by
Richard Bentley (1662-1742) Bentley, Richard, 1662-1742 , Master of Trinity.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue
Überlieferung und Bestand der hagiographischen und homiletischen Literatur der griechischen Kirche: von den Anfängen bis zum Ende des 16. Jahrhunderts
Überlieferung und Bestand der hagiographischen und homiletischen Literatur der griechischen Kirche

series.title: Texte und Untersuchungen zur Geschichte der altchristlichen Literatur

msItem.author: Athanasios of Alexandria
msItem.title: Vita Antonii
msItem.incipit: f. i verso φαιδρότερος μᾶλλον αὐτὸν ἐφαίνετο καὶ πρὸς ἰσχὺν προθυμότερος
msItem.explicit: f. i recto ὡς πλάνους καὶ φθορέας τῶν ἀνθρώπων τυγχάνοντας· ἐν Χριστῶ Ἰησοῦ Κυρίω ἡμῶν· ὧ ἡ δόξα· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας· ἀμήν

supportDesc.condition: There are substantial tears and holes in the folio, extensive and severe mould staining and water staining.

layoutDesc.layout:
Two columns of 30 lines. 225 140
f. i verso-i recto Ruled in hardpoint, type Leroy 20C2. Text hangs from the lines. The text on f. i recto, comprising the end of this work, is arranged in a single column in an ornamental shape.

handNote.p: f. i verso-i recto was copied by Hand A, in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. Use of the double dot is functional only. There is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of a section is marked by a simple minor initial in red ink.

physDesc.additions: There is a note on f. i recto, partially lost to cropping and ending Γεωργίου τῶν Φρυγανῶν. A similar note in a different hand appears on f. i verso: τῶν Φρυγανῶν τοῦ ἁγίου, followed by an abbreviated name of uncertain transcription.

history.origin: The manuscript from which this folio came was probably copied in the second half of the 11th or first half of the 12th century, as suggested by the style of script.

msItem.title: March
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Μὴν Μάρτιος ἔχει ἡμέρας λαʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας ιβʹ καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὥρας ιβʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Οὗτος ἀρχὴ μηνῶν καὶ πρῶτος διἀγορεύεται

msItem.title: April
msItem.rubric: f. 41r Μὴν Ἀπρίλλιος ἔχει ἡμέρας λʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας ιγʹ καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὥρας ιαʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 41r Εἰς τὴν αʹ· μνήμη τῆς ὁσίας Μαρίας τῆς Αἰγυπτίας

msItem.title: May
msItem.rubric: f. 71r Μὴν Μάϊος· ἔχει ἡμέρας, λαʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας, ιδʹ καὶ ἡ νὺξ, ὥρας, ιʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 71r Ἐν τῆ αʹ. μνήμη τοῦ ἁγίου προφήτου Ἱερεμίου
msItem.explicit: f. 101r Ἰλιγγιῶσιν οὐδαμῶς πρὸς πῦρ φλέγων

msItem.title: June
msItem.rubric: f. 101v Μὴν Ἰούνιος ἔχει ἡμέρας λʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας ιεʹ καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὥρας θʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 101v Ἐν τῆ αʹ. μνήμη τοῦ ἁγίου προφήτου φιλοσόφου
msItem.explicit: f. 131r ζητῶν ἐφευρεῖν τὸν καλὸν μαργαρίτην

msItem.title: July
msItem.rubric: f. 131r Μὴν Ἰούλλιος ἔχει ἡμέρας λαʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας ιδʹ καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὥρας ιʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 131r Μνήμη τῶν ἁγίων μαρτύρων καὶ ἀναργύρων Κοσμᾶ καὶ Δαμιανοῦ τῶν Ῥωμαίων
msItem.explicit: f. 153r ἔνθα ἀπόκειται ἡ ἁγία Σόρος

msItem.title: August
msItem.rubric: f. 153r Μὴν Αὔγουστος· ἔχει ἡμέρας, λαʹ· ἡ ἡμέρα ἔχει ὥρας ιγʹ· καὶ ἡ νὺξ ὥρας ιαʹ
msItem.incipit: f. 153r Εἰς τὴν αʹ· μνήμη τῶν ἁγίων Μακκαββαίων Ἐλεαζάρου, καὶ Σολομωνίδος
msItem.explicit: f. 183v φθᾶσαι τὸ τέρμα τῆς παρούσης πυκτίδος

support.material: Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and poor quality.

collation.p: This part consists of 24 quires, of which one is a binion, one a ternion, and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 178-1 ff. 127-133 The fifth folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 198-1 ff. 142-148 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 228-1 ff. 165-171 The seventh folio has been lost, with loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in brown ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower left, probably original to the production of the manuscript. Some have been lost to cropping. They survive on Quires 3-9 and 14-16 (γʹ-θʹ, ιδʹ-ιϛʹ), and traces of their ornament on Quires 10-11 and 22.

Later quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, have been added on the last folio of each quire, verso, lower left. Some have been lost to cropping. The number 18 has been skipped, so from this point on the numbers are too large by one. These signatures survive in whole or in part on Quires 3-23 (γʹ-ιζʹ, ιθʹ-κδʹ).

signatures.p: Quire signatures in pencil, in Greek numerals, have been added on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right, on Quires 1-6 and 9-24: (αʹ-ϛʹ, θʹ-κδʹ). Those for Quires 18 and 19 are misplaced.

supportDesc.condition: There are splits in ff. 43 and 141, and tears to the edges of some folios, most notably ff. 55, 95, 125, 146, 158, 173 and 180-182. Pest damage is present in the outer folios at each end of the manuscript (ff. 1-36, 176-183). There is some cockling and creasing. There is water staining, extensive in the latter part of the manuscript, areas of dirt and spillages of black and red ink.

layoutDesc.layout:
Two columns of 36 lines. 220 140
Pricking survives in the upper and lower margins, but much has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 20C2. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-178r were copied by Hand B, in a somewhat unsteady mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in brown ink. There is little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. The double grave accent is in use. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and nomina sacra strokes. Horizontal strokes appear above proper nouns. Marginal quotation marks are used.
There are inclusions of letters within omicron.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in pale red ink, apart from those for each month, which are written in epigraphic display majuscule.
Many faded portions of the text have later been overwritten in black ink.
ff. 178v-183v were copied by Hand C, in an upright mixed minuscule script, in black ink. There is little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. The double grave accent is in use. Horizontal strokes appear above proper nouns.
There are inclusions of letters within omicron.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in bright red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The first heading of the text (f. 1r) is surrounded by a square border headpiece in red ink. Other headings are preceded by rectangular or thin plaited headpieces (ff. 41r, 71r, 101v, 131r, 153r).

Hagiographic sections on ff. 1r-178r begin with enlarged ornamented initials in red ink, while the preceding hymnographic notes begin with initials slightly larger than normal letters in red ink. On ff. 178v-183v both types of section begin with simple minor initials of a single type.
Simple vignettes in red and brown ink precede entries for days.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional brief marginal notes and pen-trials. Practice drawings of initials and other ornament have been drawn on f. 183v.

history.origin: The manuscript was probably copied in the late 12th or 13th century, as suggested by the style of script.
